macro.name: VIX index
macro.note: VIX at 17.86 (2025-11-13 4:00 PM EST). Heightened complacency is a risk factor.

macro.name: Gold price (GLD)
macro.note: Gold (GLD) is rallying sharply at $385.99. Indicates rising inflation expectations or systemic risk.

macro.name: EUR/USD exchange rate
macro.note: EUR/USD is stable at 1.1618. Indicates balanced global risk/economic outlook.

macro.name: WTI crude oil ($/bbl)
macro.note: WTI Crude at $58.30/bbl. Low price indicates global slowdown or demand weakness.

macro.name: AUD/USD exchange rate
macro.note: AUDUSD at 0.6575. AUD is consolidating. Global risk appetite is tentative.

macro.name: US 3yr treasury yield
macro.action: Avoid intermediate locks; prefer short/floating rate instruments.

macro.name: US 30yr treasury yield
macro.note: Yield at 4.71%. Elevated long-term yields reflecting fiscal risk/inflation concerns.
macro.action: Watch the 5.0% threshold. Limit long duration locks.

macro.name: US 10yr treasury yield
macro.action: Watch the Atlas pivot at 4.75%; favour short duration.

macro.name: High yield OAS (bps)
macro.note: HY OAS at 302 bps. US credit stress is low and manageable.

macro.name: Treasury net liquidity
macro.note: Net Liquidity at $6571785B. Liquidity is robust and supportive of risk assets.

micro.name: S&P 500 index
micro.note: S&P 500 Index at 6,851. Strong/stable price action. Low systemic equity risk.

micro.name: ASX 200 index
micro.note: ASX 200 Index at 8,753. Stable price action.

micro.name: Put/Call ratio (PCCE)
micro.note: PCEE Ratio at 0.50. Low hedging (call-buying dominance). High complacency/bullish sentiment.
micro.action: Implement small hedges; avoid chasing market highs.

micro.name: FINRA margin debt (YOY %)
micro.note: Margin Debt YOY at 32.9% (FINRA Data, Oct 2025, Not Seasonally Adjusted). Leverage is expanding aggressively. High risk of forced liquidation if markets fall.
micro.action: Aggressively deleverage equity exposure; increase cash.

micro.name: Small/Large cap ratio
micro.note: Ratio at 0.3577 — small-caps are heavily underperforming. Poor internals.

micro.name: SOFR OIS Spread (bps)
micro.note: SOFR/OIS spread is -5.0 bps. Dollar funding market is stable.

micro.name: Bank CDS index (bps)
micro.note: Bank CDS at 5 bps. Low implied banking stress.

micro.name: Credit card delinquencies
micro.note: Delinquency Rate at 305.0%. Rate is spiking. Signals severe consumer stress.
micro.action: Aggressively reduce exposure to consumer discretionary and financial stocks with high unsecured loan exposure.

overall.comment: Market stability deteriorating rapidly. High caution required.
overall.daily_narrative:
The Atlas Composite Score registers a SEVERE RISK posture at 8.50, driven by critical Red indicators in leverage and persistent Amber signals across duration risk. Most notably, FINRA margin debt has surged to 32.94% year-over-year, signaling excessive speculative leverage within the equity market, while credit card delinquencies have reached 305.00, underscoring significant stress in consumer balance sheets. These leverage metrics are compounded by a Red signal from the Small/Large cap ratio at 0.36, indicating a clear flight to quality within equities and a preference for larger, more stable companies over smaller, more growth-sensitive firms. Simultaneously, duration risk remains elevated, with the US 3-year, 10-year, and 30-year Treasury yields all in Amber status at 3.56%, 4.13%, and 4.71% respectively, reflecting ongoing upward pressure on borrowing costs across the curve.
A notable contradiction exists in the VIX index, which remains at an Amber 17.86, suggesting a degree of market complacency despite the severe underlying leverage and duration risks. This divergence implies that while systemic vulnerabilities are accumulating, market participants may not yet be fully pricing in the potential for a sharp correction. Furthermore, Treasury net liquidity and the SOFR OIS Spread remain Green, indicating that immediate, broad-based systemic liquidity stress is not currently evident, which could be a lagging indicator or a reflection of existing central bank backstops. For investors, this environment necessitates a defensive stance, prioritizing capital preservation and reducing exposure to assets highly sensitive to credit tightening and rising rates. The confluence of high leverage and increasing duration risk points to a fragile financial landscape where even minor catalysts could trigger significant market volatility.
Globally, the macro and policy tone remains complex, as highlighted by Reuters reporting on the Federal Reserve's internal divisions, with some officials expressing hesitation to support further rate hikes, suggesting a potential pause or slower pace in monetary tightening. Concurrently, Reuters also noted the Yen's continued weakness against the Euro, influenced by Japan's Prime Minister signaling a cautious approach to rate increases. Despite these developments, Reuters observed that markets appear to be navigating 2025's upheavals with "puzzling ease," even as the US shutdown was resolved. Economic data presents a mixed picture, with Bloomberg reporting a fall in Australian unemployment, while the Wall Street Journal highlighted weak UK data potentially cementing a downtrend for Sterling. These external factors underscore a global environment characterized by divergent economic performance and cautious central bank postures, against a backdrop of underlying financial system stress. Readers are directed to the News Feed below for the full list of articles reviewed.
The Atlas posture would escalate to FULL-STORM should the US 10-Year Yield move above 4.75% or High Yield OAS widen beyond 400 bps.
overall.composite_summary: The Atlas Composite Score of 8.50 signals a SEVERE RISK environment, driven by escalating leverage and duration risks, despite a degree of market complacency.
key_actions: Reduce exposure to highly leveraged assets and speculative credit segments.
Increase allocation to defensive equity sectors and high-quality, dividend-paying companies.
Implement tactical hedges against potential equity market downside and rising interest rates.
Closely monitor High Yield OAS for any widening beyond the 400 bps threshold, indicating further credit deterioration.
Re-evaluate duration exposure in fixed income portfolios, favoring shorter-duration instruments to mitigate interest rate risk.
